overview: Using clinical cases to illustrate principles, this subject examines the structure, function and potential for dysfunction of the digestive system of the major domestic animal species. As students develop an understanding of the mechanisms of disease of this system, they will develop skills in the clinical evaluation of it and in the interpretation of relevant diagnostic procedures.
intended learning outcomes: Compare and contrast the structure and function of the digestive systems of different species
Differentiate normal and abnormal structures of the digestive system on gross observation and in histological preparations and diagnostic images
Explain the processes by which normal function of the digestive system may be disrupted and predict the outcomes of perturbations
Apply an understanding of the mechanism of action of common classes of drugs that act on the digestive system to explain their use in the treatment of digestive diseases

Work collaboratively, communicate effectively, and apply an understanding of the structure and function of the digestive tract in order to analyse and interpret clinical problems related to this system in animals

additional pre-requisite: Admission into the MC-DVETMED Doctor of Veterinary Medicine

assessments.description: Up to four online quizzes of case study exercises, each taking approximately 30 minutes to complete, each equally weighted.. 2 hours
Written examination. 2 hours. Hurdle requirement:. Students must achieve a minimum mark of 40% in the written examination to be eligible to pass the subject.
Aggregate mark. Hurdle requirement:. Students must pass the subject on aggregate mark.

Semester 1.Contact hours: 72 hours of lectures, case studies and practical classes

Prescribed texts: There are no specifically prescribed or recommended texts for this subject.
